34th International Conference on High Energy Physics, Philadelphia, 2008

Measurement of CP Observables in B − → D 0 K − Decays at CDF
Karen R. Gibson on behalf of the CDF Collaboration
University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15260

arXiv:0809.4809v2 [hep-ex] 20 Oct 2008

This paper describes the determination of the direct CP observables RCP + and ACP + , related to the CKM angle γ,
using B − → D0 K − decays in 1.0 fb−1 of data collected with the CDF II detector. This is the first measurement of
these CP observables made at a hadron collider in this decay mode. The results presented are consistent with the
measurements of these quantities made by the Belle and BABAR collaborations.

1. INTRODUCTION
Over the past twenty years, there have been many efforts to determine the length of the sides and the angles of
the well-known Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) unitarity triangle for light B mesons [1], which is constructed
from the first and third columns of the CKM quark mixing matrix [2]. At present, good knowledge of the CKM
angle β has been established by the Belle and BABAR collaborations [3]. However, comparable knowledge of the
other CKM angles γ and α is lacking, due to limited statistics in the decay channels sensitive to these angles, such
as B − → D0 K − in the case of γ and B 0 → π + π − in the case of α.
This paper concerns the determination of CP observables in the decay B − → D0 K − [4], which provide sensitivity

Daniel Wyler (GLW) in the early 1990s [5]. These CP observables are constructed from the measurement of relative
branching ratios and from CP asymmetries. Previously, measurements of these quantities, and of γ by extension,
have only been made at the B factories. Since these measurements have been limited by statistical accuracy, the
experiments at the Tevatron have an opportunity to contribute significantly to the determination of these quantities,
particularly when considering the large amount of B hadron data that remains to be collected and analyzed before
the end of Run II. This paper presents the first measurement of the CP observables constructed in B − → D0 K −
decays at a hadron collider, using 1.0 fb−1 of data that was collected between February 2002 and February 2006.

of γ in B − → D0 K − decays by using CP-even or odd decays of the D0 . The asymmetry between the B − and B +
amplitudes of decays to a D0 CP eigenstate can be related to the amplitudes of decays to a flavor-specific D0 decay

3. MEASUREMENT OF CP OBSERVABLES AT CDF
The CDF II detector is described in detail elsewhere [7]. The data used in the present measurement is collected
with a track-based trigger that requires two displaced tracks to satisfy individual and combined minimum transverse
momenta thresholds [8]. The relative branching ratios in Eqs. (2) and (3) are measured in a simultaneous maximum
likelihood fit, which uses both kinematic information, such as the invariant mass of the B − system, which is reconstructed as D0 π − , and daughter particle momenta, and the specific ionization of the daughter track from the B − in
order to separate kaons and pions.
To choose the signal selection requirements, the sensitivity to the primary quantity of interest, ACP + , is optimized
using pseudo-experiments. A likelihood fit is performed in the invariant mass window m(D0 π − ) ∈ [5.17, 5.60] GeV/c2 .
This requirement reduces backgrounds from decays other than B − → D(∗)0 π − . Additionally, events which fall
within a ±2σ window around the B + → J/ψ K + are removed from the sample to reduce contamination in the
B − → D0 [→ π − π + ]K − . However, it is worthwhile to note that background events from B − → K − K + K − cannot
be eliminated and must be included in the likelihood fit.
Six identical likelihoods are constructed, one set each for B + and B − and three in each set corresponding to the

From the likelihood fit, we obtain raw yields for the six decays, two of which are shown in Fig. 2. The ratios R and
ACP + obtained from these yields are corrected using Monte Carlo simulation to account for the relative efficiencies
between the decay modes. Small biases observed in pseudo-experiments, on the level of 1-2%, are corrected for as
well.

4. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES
A number of sources of systematic uncertainty are evaluated for the ratios R, RCP + , and ACP + . The largest
sources of systematic uncertainty are due to particle flavor identification (dE/dx) and the correlation between α

of the invariant mass sidebands, so its knowledge will improve with increased data. The description of the invariant
mass of the D∗0 π − is also a significant source of systematic uncertainty in the measurement of R. Other sources
of systematic uncertainties considered are the uncertainty on the value of the B − mass [9], the mass model of the
combinatoric background, the knowledge of correlations between α and ptot in the D0 π − , D∗0 π − , and D0 K − PDFs,
the small bias observed in pseudo-experiments, and the statistics of the simulated sample used to correct relative
efficiencies. The systematic uncertainties assigned are listed in Tab. I.

5. RESULTS
The final results for R, RCP + and ACP + , corrected for relative efficiencies and including systematic uncertainties,
are
R = 0.0745 ± 0.0043 (stat) ± 0.0043 (syst),
RCP + = 1.30 ± 0.24 (stat) ± 0.12 (syst),
ACP + = 0.39 ± 0.17 (stat) ± 0.04 (syst).

Additionally, RCP + and ACP + are compared with the results from Belle and BABAR in Fig. 3. This measurement
represents a significant achievement for a hadron collider experiment, as it is the first time these CP observables have
been measured in such a complicated environment. This result will be submitted shortly to Phys. Rev. D Rapid
Communications and we anticipate updates to the measurement that make use of more data in the near future.
